guidecontent.title: Purpose
guidecontent.data:
Ultrasound guided peripheral I.V. insertion (UGPIVI) promotes I.V. catheter placement in veins that are deeper than those visible or palpable by the care provider and is beneficial when use of traditional I.V. insertion techniques, such as blood vessel palpation or visualization, is not possible or would be difficult.

Ultrasound in Peripheral I.V. Placement

  • Broadband high-resolution linear array transducers

  • Frequency between 7.5-12 MHz

  • Higher frequencies for less deep vessels

  • Lower frequencies for deeper vessels

  • Smaller size probes for pediatric patients and anatomical areas with limited space

Impossible or Difficult I.V. Insertion

  • Obesity

  • Edema

  • Vein-debilitating disease such as cancer or sickle cell disease

  • Exposure to cold or in shock

  • Low circulating blood volume

  • Pediatric patients

  • History of multiple I.V. insertions

  • History of difficult I.V. access

Indications for Use of UGPIVI

  • Failed cannulation via traditional insertion methods

  • Severe dehydration

  • Obesity

  • Peripheral edema

  • History of/scarring from multiple cannulations

  • Sickle cell disease

  • Burned skin over the cannulation site

Benefits of UGPIVI

  • More accurate than Doppler assistance or palpation

  • Allows for visualization of changes in artery structure and location during needle advancement

  • Decreased number of I.V. attempts/needle sticks

  • Rapid cannulation compared to multiple failed attempts using the traditional method

  • Decreased discomfort in patients that are a �hard stick�

  • More rapid access to treatment

  • Avoids the use of central venous access in nonemergent patient cases

guidecontent.title: Red Flags
guidecontent.data:
• Extensive training is required to avoid potentially damaging arteries and nerves that lie parallel to deep veins accessible via UGPIVI

  • Do not puncture a vessel that pulsates upon palpation as this indicates arterial flow

  • Avoid overly deep needle placement by acknowledging centimeter markings, indicating depth of scanning, visible along the edge of the ultrasound image

  • Caution must be used with administration of vesicant and irritant solutions as infiltration of deep veins is not detectable until a large amount of fluid has pooled in the tissue

guidecontent.title: Nursing Considerations
guidecontent.data:
• Use of UGPIVI is not necessary when it is possible to insert a peripheral I.V. using a traditional technique without difficulty

  • UGPIVI is performed by trained nurses, emergency room physicians and technicians

  • UGPIVI should only be performed by nurses that have received training on the procedure and have demonstrated ongoing competence

  • UGPIVI can be performed via the transverse or longitudinal approach. Care providers performing UGPIVI should be familiar with both techniques. More about transverse/longitudinal UGPIVI approach

  • Contraindications to UGPIVI do not exist. See considerations prior to UGPIVI

  • Identification of vessels is important to identify veins from arteries. More about identifying veins from arteries

  • Insertion sites when using UGPIVI include the hand, forearm or antecubital veins, and upper arm or basilica, cephalic, and brachial veins. See areas to avoid for UGPIVI

  • Vein depth greater than 1.5-2cm (0.60-0.79 inches) is difficult to access even with ultrasound guidance

  • Successful peripheral I.V. catheterization is more likely with a vein that is larger in diameter as the depth of the vein is less important than the diameter of the vein

  • Dynamic ultrasound view during insertion is considered superior to the static ultrasound view

  • It is ideal to start UGPIVI in the short-view to verify the needle is over the middle of the vessel and then switch to a long-view when advancing the needle

  • Potential complications of UGPIVI include arterial puncture and paresthesia as a result of nerve injury

Transverse/Longitudinal UGPIVI Approach

Transverse approach

  • Simpler to learn this technique

  • Provides a cross-sectional view of the vasculature

  • Simultaneously view anatomical structures, veins, and arteries

  • Circular structures viewed are vessels

Longitudinal approach

  • Promotes better needle visualization

Considerations Prior to UGPIVI

  • Skin breakdown at the potential insertion site

  • Burned skin over the potential insertion site

  • Presence of arteriovenous fistulas

  • History of deep vein thrombosis

  • History of lymph-node dissection following a mastectomy

  • Anticipation of long-term I.V. access that will be needed beyond 6 days warranting central line insertion

Identifying Veins from Arteries

  • Veins- will easily collapse completely when pressure is applied via US probe application

  • Arteries- visibly pulsate and will not completely collapse when pressure is applied via US probe application

Areas to Avoid for UGPIVI

  • Extremity on the side of a mastectomy, arteriovenous shunt, fistula, paralysis, or lymph node dissection

  • Site within a moveable area of a joint

  • Vein that feels cordlike or firm

  • Previous catheter sites

  • Skin inflammation such as dermatitis or cellulitis

  • Veins on the surface of the hand in older adults and active adults

Factors Promoting Successful Cannulation

  • Large diameter of the vein

  • Less depth of the vein in the surrounding tissue

  • Decreased tortuosity of the vein

Catheter Length Based on Vein Depth

A longer I.V. catheter is needed for veins that are greater than 1cm below the skin�s surface:

  • < 1cm deep � standard catheter (3.2cm/1.26 inches long)

  • > 1cm and up to 2 cm deep - angiocatheter (6.4 cm/2.52 inches long)

  • 2 cm or more deep- specialized catheter required

Ultrasound Views

Static approach vs. dynamic approach:

  • Static � use of real-time ultrasound to identify surrounding structures, vessel location, and patency to mark the location of optimal insertion. The remainder of the procedure is done without real-time guidance

  • Dynamic- use of real-time ultrasound to view the needle as it enters the vessel and is advanced

Short View and Long View

  • In short, or out-of-plane, view the image plane is perpendicular to the vessel. The vessel will appear as a circle and the needle appears as a cross-section of the circle

  • In long, or in-plane, view the image plane is parallel to the vessel. The vessel appears across the screen and the needle is in view as it advances

data.title: Research
data.data:
In a study of 749 patients, comparing radial artery cannulation success on the first attempt via ultrasound, palpation, and Doppler assistance, the rate of cannulation on the first attempt via ultrasound was increased by 14%.8

In one study, of 418 patients in a pediatric emergency department, researchers did not support investing in ultrasound imaging devices for peripheral I.V. placement as ultrasound guidance did not increase first attempt success rates of peripheral I.V. placement.2

data.title: Guidelines
data.data:
UGPIVI should not occur at a location that bends or flexes. If a catheter is placed near a joint that bends a device to stabilize the joint should be applied.7

Alternative insertion methods should be considered for vessels that are beyond 1.5 cm deep.7

UGPIVI can be performed with or without a tourniquet.7

Peripheral I.V. catheter placement is recommended by using the transverse view with catheter placement being confirmed by switching to the longitudinal view. The inserting health care provider should confirm proper placement by visualizing the catheter tip both during and following insertion.7

Single provider UGPIVI is recommended as it can be difficult to coordinate the necessary steps required when using 2 people to insert the catheter.5

The use of a second care provider during UGPIVI to retract the skin and keep it taut is appropriate for care providers with limited line insertion experience.7

data.title: Supplies
data.data:
• Personal protective equipment (PPE)

  • Ultrasound machine and linear array probe

  • Sterile ultrasound probe cover or sheath

  • Sterile ultrasound gel

  • Nonsterile ultrasound gel

  • Peripheral I.V. catheters, 18 or 20 gauge, and greater than 4.45cm/1.75 inches long

  • I.V. extension tubing

  • Saline flush

  • Gauze pads

  • Topical or injectable site anesthetic and delivery device

  • Tourniquet

  • Antiseptic to clean the site

data.title: Pre-Procedure Steps
data.data:
1. Review the facility/unit-specific protocol for UGPIVI, if one is available

  2. Review the treating clinician�s order for peripheral I.V. insertion via ultrasound guidance

  3. Review the patient�s medical history/medical record

  4. Follow standard pre-procedure steps

  5. Place the patient in a supine or sitting position

  6. Raise or lower the height of the patient and the monitor to avoid having to bend or turn your head to view images

  7. Position the patient in a lying or sitting position with their arm flat on a horizontal surface

  8. Rotate the arm to achieve access to the proposed insertion site

  9. Clean the transducer with a facility approved solution

data.title: Procedure Steps
data.data:
1. Place nonsterile ultrasound gel on the ultrasound probe1

  2. Place a sterile transparent cover or sheath over the ultrasound probe7

  3. Place sterile ultrasound gel on the ultrasound probe sheath1

  4. Adjust settings on the transducer so that vessels appear in the center of the screen and are black in color4

  5. Administer or apply site anesthetic as ordered1

  6. Place a tourniquet on the patient�s arm proximal to the insertion site1 4

  7. Place the ultrasound device in a transverse orientation to insert via the transverse technique4

  8. Scan the arm by moving the transducer up and down in the chosen insertion area to locate the target vein5

  9. Confirm the ultrasound image lines up with the same side of the transducer. For example, the left side of image and left side of transducer4

  10. Identify a vein for cannulation4

  11. Determine the depth of the vein4

  12. Swab the skin at the site with an antiseptic solution4

  13. Hold the I.V. catheter needle with your dominant hand at a 45� angle to the skin4 5

  14. Hold the ultrasound probe with your nondominant hand5

  15. Insert the needle into the skin4

  16. Advance the needle in the direction of the vein4

  17. Avoid failing to advance the ultrasound probe simultaneously as the I.V. catheter is advanced5

  18. Look for the needle tip as repeating artifact or a single bright dot with posterior shadowing on the transducer screen4

  19. Drag or fan the transducer probe gently over the site or bounce/vibrate the needle slightly while looking for movement of adjacent soft tissue and the needle tip on the transducer screen, if unable to view the needle tip4

  20. Continue to advance the needle into the vein4

  21. Avoid passing the needle through the posterior vessel wall5

  22. Tilt the transducer in the direction that the needle is traveling4

  23. Assess for blood return which indicates the needle has entered the vein4

  24. Acknowledge that a lack of blood return indicates the needle may have passed through the posterior wall of the vessel5

  25. Decrease the angle of the needle4

  26. Advance the needle 1-2 cm4

  27. Secure the needle with your nondominant hand4

  28. Use a forward motion to advance the catheter over the needle and into the vein4

  29. Place the ultrasound device in a transverse orientation to insert via the longitudinal technique4

  30. Scan the arm by moving the transducer up and down in the chosen insertion area to locate the target vein5

  31. Rotate the transducer 90�4

  32. Identify the side of the image that represents the distal vein4

  33. Secure the transducer on the patient with your nondominant hand4

  34. Swab the skin at the site with an antiseptic solution4

  35. Hold the needle at a 30� angle with your dominant hand4

  36. Insert the needle at the center of the long axis of the transducer4

  37. Advance the needle within the ultrasound plane4

  38. Back up and redirect the needle as needed if the vein but not the needle is in view4

  39. Advance the needle only if the tip is visible4

  40. Use a quick forward movement to pierce the vein and avoid vein compression in response to the needle4

  41. Visually identify the needle tip inside the vein4

  42. Use a forward motion to advance the catheter over the needle and into the vein4

  43. Visualize the catheter advance forward an off the needle into the vein4

  44. Stop advancing the catheter if resistance is met as this indicates improper positioning of the catheter1

  45. Verify blood return is viewed in the catheter1

  46. Remove the tourniquet, if applied5

  47. Secure the catheter per facility protocol4

  48. Flush the catheter with normal saline4

data.title: Patient/Family Education
data.data:
• Explain the procedure to the patient and family members. Answer any questions they may have

  • Reinforce the benefit of using UGPIVI verses traditional insertion techniques

  • Explain that the ultrasound device will not be uncomfortable, but that they will feel a small prick when the needle is inserted

  • Reinforce the importance of keeping the affected extremity still during the procedure

data.title: Post-Procedure Steps
data.data:
1. Follow standard post-procedure steps

  2. Label any images obtained during insertion with patient and facility identifying information. See images obtained during UGPIVI

Images Obtained During UGPIVI

  • Pre-procedure venous patency and surrounding anatomy

  • Needle tip placement into the vessel

  • Post-procedure flush of the vessel

data.title: Documentation
data.data:
Update the patient�s plan of care and medical record , as appropriate. Include:

  • Date and time peripheral I.V. catheter was inserted using ultrasound guidance

  • I.V. catheter type, length and gauge

  • Anesthetic type, dose and administration method, if used

  • Description of ultrasound view used

  • Description of needle visualization during insertion

  • I.V. catheter insertion site & vessel patency

  • Verification of successful insertion and vessel placement

  • Patient�s tolerance of the procedure

  • Any unexpected patient events, interventions performed, and if the treating clinician was notified, and patient outcome

  • All patient/family member education, including topics presented, response to education provided, plan for follow-up education, identified barriers to communication, and techniques that promoted successful communication

guidecontent.title: Nursing Outcomes
guidecontent.data: • Successful peripheral I.V. placement is achieved when the use of traditional I.V. insertion techniques is not possible or would be difficult, with the assistance of ultrasound guidance, into veins that are deeper than those visible or palpable by the care provider

GUID-5129D412-E8E0-4ADC-AEFA-038B856AF44.title: Patient's Medical History/Medical Record
GUID-5129D412-E8E0-4ADC-AEFA-038B856AF44.data:
• Information about allergies. Use alternatives, as appropriate

  • Indications for peripheral I.V. placement via ultrasound guidance

  • Anatomic issues at the proposed insertion site

  • Prior needle sticks at the proposed insertion site

  • History of coagulopathy

GUID-5129D412-E8E0-4ADC-AEFA-038B856AF44.title: Standard Pre-Procedure Steps
GUID-5129D412-E8E0-4ADC-AEFA-038B856AF44.data:
1. Verify completion of facility informed consent documents, if necessary

  2. Check the orders and care plan

  3. Review the manufacturer�s instructions for all supplies to be used, and verify that they are in good working order

  4. Maintain level of infection precautions, as appropriate

  5. Provide privacy for the patient

  6. Identify the patient

  7. Introduce yourself

  8. Explain the procedure

  9. Perform hand hygiene according to facility protocol, and don PPE, as appropriate

  10. Assess general health status, including pain level and provide prescribed analgesic, if necessary, before proceeding

  11. Recruit other staff members to assist as necessary

GUID-5129D412-E8E0-4ADC-AEFA-038B856AF44.title: Standard Post-Procedure Steps
GUID-5129D412-E8E0-4ADC-AEFA-038B856AF44.data:
1. Dispose of used materials

  2. Maintain patient safety

  3. Discard used procedure materials in appropriate receptacles

  4. Perform hand hygiene
